description: From Middle French offensif, from Medieval Latin offensivus, from Latin offendere (“to offend”), past participle offensus; see offend.

adjectives.description: offensive (comparative more offensive, superlative most offensive)

entries.meaning: Causing offense; arousing a visceral reaction of disgust, anger, hatred, or indignation.
Relating to an offense or attack, as opposed to defensive.
examples: The army's offensive capabilities. An offensive weapon.

entries.meaning: (sports) Having to do with play directed at scoring.
examples: The offensive coordinator is responsible for ordering all rushing plays.
The Marines today launched a major offensive.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The posture of attacking or being able to attack.
examples: He took the offensive in the press, accusing his opponent of corruption.
